I surely do not and, after discussions with my colleagues on that committee, I know they do not support it.

My dissenting report which I put forward to the committee went one step further. I do not believe in just banning the taking of black and blue marlin by commercial operators, I believe there is no need to take any billfish at all. Whilst there is a market for broadbill and a market for striped marlin, because those are actually quite good to eat, the reality is black and blue marlin cannot differentiate between the baits meant for striped marlin.

Most marlin are surface water feeders whereas tuna are deeper water feeders. By banning marlin captures altogether you will find that these long-liners will set their hooks—and it is a different style of hook if you are only going to target tuna—at deeper depths, getting them down quicker to avoid the albatrosses and surface fish that they are not targeting.

The reality is that as we start to strip out these species of fish we affect one of the great industries that we have in Australia, the tourism industry. The tourism industry based on game fishing is worth millions of dollars to the Australian economy. It can be said that for each marlin taken in commercial fishing there is a potential $40,000 loss to the tourism industry.

In my dissenting report I also recommended allowing recreational fishermen to be a part of the management authority to enable them to have direct input, even though they have that input now. However, the government is looking at charging them on a cost recovery basis. In the game fishing charter industry at the moment they are already paying a fair amount of tax, or more than a fair amount of tax. For example, they are paying sales tax on their charter boats whereas commercial fishermen do not, and they are paying excise on their diesel fuel whereas commercial fishermen do not. I think they are already contributing enough to our economy and there is no need for additional charges. Therefore, I disagree with some of the recommendations made by the committee

The announcement by Senator Parer, Minister for Resources and Energy, on 5 November to protect black marlin and blue marlin by banning their capture is welcomed by all. In particular, it is welcomed by the Game Fishing Association of Australia. In their release of 5 November, Bob Lowe said that this, together with developing a Commonwealth by‐catch policy for commercial long‐liners in the wider voluntary ban area of area E will minimise the by‐catch of black marlin and blue marlin and support the efforts to protect sustainability in area E. The release also states that, by protecting the fisheries, we have long‐term tourist industry development. Further, a report by the Australian Fishing Tackle Association, AFTA, stated that every marlin caught off Cairns injects some $40,000 worth of tourism money into the Australian economy.

But we should not be thinking about these fish that are being caught as being caught and killed. The majority of game fish in Australia, and particularly billfish, are tagged and released by the game fishing associations. In light of our report, the Game Fishing Association has decided to raise the minimum weight for marlin captures from 60 kilograms to 80 kilograms, with still no size restriction for tag and release. One of the beaut aspects of tag and release is that it provides ongoing research and information for these billfish developments.

Area E has been important to the fisheries, as it is recognised as being one of the greatest spawning grounds. For marlin, it was back in 1990 that ETUMAC initially recommended a ban on all fishing in area E. That was not adhered to and fishing licences were issued, but through negotiation and discussion the fishing industry, together with the recreational fishing industry, has set up a six‐point agreement on allowing fishing in area E off Cairns.

That six‐point agreement recognises that commercial operators do have a legitimate right to fish in the area, but it sets out a number of agreed restrictions, including the non‐retention of all billfish except marlin broadbill, which is caught in totally different areas and depths from that of striped, black, blue marlin or short‐billed spearfish types of game fish. It is to be highly commended when people can sit down and work through the processes and the problems to deliver long‐term solutions.

From the outset, I also need to declare that I do have a pecuniary interest in game fishing. I am a very avid fisherman, and one of my marlin captures is now mounted on the wall of my office in parliament house because it reflects the spirit of my area of Port Stephens, which is second to and sometimes even greater in catch capacity than Cairns in billfish. It has long been recognised as being one of the homes of game fishing in Australia. Last year in our four‐day competition 1,032 marlin were caught but, more importantly, tagged and released to go back into the ocean to continue their cycles of growth and spawning.

Fisheries management in Australia over the years has not exactly been something that we can be proud of. We need only to have a look at the gemfish problem that we had in Australia. Gemfish catches were allowed for many years when this new fishery was found until they were wiped out to all but extinction. Over the last four years, whilst there has been a ban on gemfish, the numbers have grown, and I understand that this year we have allowed a catch of some 1,200 tonnes for this season. The fishery will regrow but, with the lack of understanding, it was not realised that this fish is around about 80 to 100 years old before it is mature enough to catch it.

We also need to look at the future of all fisheries. I found an interesting article in the Times of 28 October last year when I was travelling to the South Pacific Conference with colleagues to look at the fisheries and timber industries and effects upon them in the Pacific. This article talked in part about factory trawl ships. These are ships that put out over a kilometre of purse seine net, and in one haul they can haul in some 400 tonnes of fish every couple of hours. One does not have to be Einstein to work out that, if you are pulling out that much fish, it is fish that does not proceed along through the migratory track to breed and provide long‐term fisheries.`

These trawlers are over 100 metres in length, with as many as 100 crew on board. Whilst there is a desperate need in this world to provide food for all—and fish is the staple diet of many people—we also need to make sure that the industry is long term and is sustainable. I understand from this article that the worldwide catch was something like 20 million tonnes a year in 1950, but it hit 86 million tonnes in 1989. I do not know what the total allowable catch per annum should be, but anyone giving an indication can only be guessing.

With cattle, sheep or other animals on the land, one can put them in a pen or mark off an area and then work out how many there are, but highly migratory species of fish cannot be seen from the air or penned up and counted so, at best, we can only guess the numbers. One of the ways that we guess is based on the amount of catch each year. Another factor that needs to be considered in terms of the long‐term sustainability of fishing is the effect the El Nino effect will have on the ocean currents and tides, and where we go in that direction.

In an article in the Age of 2 June 1997, Ian Verrender spelt out quite clearly the failed management of the eastern gemfish fisheries. The eastern gemfish was considered to be extinct four years ago but now, as I said, they are allowing 1,200 tonnes of gemfish to be caught this year. It was a very popular fishery in the 1970s, which peaked at more than 5,000 tonnes in 1978 but, within five years, half of that amount was caught and, in 1993, a total ban was introduced. We need to have respect for our fisheries and their long‐term viability.

The other fishery that concerns me is the southern bluefin tuna fishery. One of the things I fear is factory trawl ships coming in and depleting whole schools of these fish without leaving breeding stocks. For a fee of some $3.4 million, the Japanese are allowed to trawl 10,000 kilometres of fishing line, seven days a week, for a quota of 200 tonnes of southern bluefin tuna and an unlimited target catch of other species. The report highlighted that one of the main problems in the fisheries industry is the by‐catch. When factory trawl ships pull up 400 tonnes, generally around 25 per cent is by‐catch, so with each trawl we are looking at 100 tonnes—not 100 kilograms, not 1,000 kilograms, but 100 tonnes—of fish being dumped back into the sea.

It would be very naive to believe that the by‐catch just swims off and goes on with its breeding cycle. What happens is that they die. As they bring the fish up, the air bladder expands and the fish are not able to go back down, or they are crushed and they suffocate because of a lack of water and oxygen, so they drift back down to the bottom and become food for other fish in the ocean, or the birds pick them up on the surface.

It is no different with the prawn trawl that we have in the Northern Territory. The by‐catch there of little dollar fish and others is just disposed of over the side, and that is a waste. We need to look at what we do with those fisheries. One of the interesting recommendations in the report was that all by‐catch should be allowed to be sold, whether or not it is commercially viable. Even if the fish is made into fertiliser, a percentage of the money from that catch could go into research in areas such as by‐catch prevention.

It is also interesting to note that our prawns cannot be exported to the United States. Even with the advertising campaign of `Throw another shrimp on the barbie', they cannot use Australian prawns. The reason is quite simple. Because we do not have by‐catch excluders to stop the pick‐up of turtles, the Americans will not allow our prawns in. That issue needs to be addressed and it needs to be worked out, because the market for fine prawns in America would drive the dollar for them up higher, and that would make the industry far more viable. We need to think to the future. We need to think about long‐term sustainability and the effects of market pressures.

One of the other fisheries that worries me is the southern bluefin tuna fishery. In 1982, we took some 21,500 tonnes. That had diminished by 1996 to a catch of 5,100 tonnes. That is a decline of some 75 per cent. I would hate to see this fishery go the way of the gemfish fishery. We need to observe it, we need to look at the report, and we need to act on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter, Bob, Jnr, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of elements of the report of the Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs Committee which are important and need to be addressed, but I must say that I was disappointed in a number of the very important areas that do need to be addressed that were not addressed. The biggest fishery in Australia money‐wise and the one that is far and away of the greatest benefit to Australia is the Gulf Barramundi Restocking Association. It is a number of years ago now that I did the figures, but some $270 million worth of prawns were caught out of that area alone. That was the figure that was quoted at the time. I must apologise to the House for not having been able to verify and update that figure, but I think you will find that it is roughly correct.

SPEECH.PARA: This most important fishery in Australia is not really addressed very much in the report at all. It is vitally important because we have had barramundi closures of the season, and we have done a whole range of things to protect the prawn fishery in the gulf as well. The assistance being given now by government is almost negligible. We had a fully operational research station at Karumba, but now there is virtually no government input into Karumba at all. For a country that is going to look after and husband properly its resources, to have no research taking place whatsoever—and I would argue that that is effectively correct—is a very great disappointment to everyone associated with this huge industry in Australia.

The people of Karumba have acted themselves. I think it is one of the most important initiatives taken in Australia, and I say that with forethought. Where they are taking some 100,000 barramundi a year out of the gulf fishery—namely, through the three main rivers running into the southern Queensland part of the Gulf of Carpentaria—they have started a barramundi breeding farm at Karumba. I must single out and pay very great tribute to Robert McKinlay, Steve Emery, Rod Garett, Eric Lollo, Ricky Gunn and to all of Robert McKinlay's executive members who, out of their own money and their own energies, put together the barramundi farm at Karumba.

What they are doing there is putting 100,000 fingerling barramundi into the Norman River and 100,000 fingerling barramundi into the Albert River, which service the southern Queensland part of the Gulf of Carpentaria. The fishermen are taking out 100,000 barramundi a year. Because of the natural attrition of that 100,000 that go into the upper reaches of those three rivers and slowly swim downstream, a lot of them will be lost, eaten by other fish and die from natural causes on the way down. So we feel that we are now achieving a balance.

I make the point that the land based fishermen are only taking barramundi. There is none of the by‐catch that was spoken of by the previous speaker, the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin). That does not exist with land based barramundi fishermen. So we are no longer quarrying the resource but we are now husbanding the resource and bringing nature into a balance with that part of nature, homo sapiens, that has been taking an undue toll on that resource up to date. So we would think that the Karumba project undertaken by the initiative of the fishermen themselves has been a magnificent project. I cannot praise too highly the work done by Robert McKinlay and the executive up there who have got this huge project going.

Apart from anything else, it is very interesting to go there because they put glass windows in the big tanks. The huge barramundi will come up and have a look at you through the glass and, of course, you will have a look at them as well. They give you the opportunity to feed the barramundi. Of course, it is a terrifying experience because they snap very aggressively at your fingers when you feed them.

Having said all that, it gives me no joy to say that, where the government of Australia was paying people to work, we now have launched upon a policy of paying people not to work. The three workers there were on one of these government work for the dole schemes. They were very happy to go along. They were getting an extra $30 or $40 a week and leading very rewarding, contributing lives.

By cutting the employment of these people, what do we do? We go back to quarrying the resource. We have three people now on the unemployment rolls that have nothing to do and are bored silly. This morning the national news was talking about suicide rates among young men and murder rates. Almost invariably people who were unemployed were represented in the murder rates in Australia.

We have put three people back on the unemployment rolls. The scheme may fall over. I do not think it will, but there is a possibility it might because they have to find three wages to keep the project going. We asked the government for a tiny bit of money for some capital equipment, because the fishermen themselves are not rich people and they put out a huge amount of money personally, to expand the farm so we could produce a few extra barramundi, which would give us a cash flow that would enable us to make a profit and keep the project going and pay the three wages that needed to be paid.

Not only did the government close down the project, because the work for the dole scheme was closed down, but in addition to that, we now pay these people the same amount of money. We pay them not to work, instead of paying them to work. Not only do we have a real possibility—not probability, I hope—of losing the scheme, but also three extra people are now sitting around with nothing to do. They are bored and living very unfulfilling lives. We are going back, if the scheme falls over, to quarrying instead of husbanding the resource as we have been doing for the last two years now.

I tell you this to tell you a really wonderful story, but a story that maybe will not have a happy ending. It will not have a happy ending due to, as far as I can see, the nearsightedness of government decision making down here in Canberra.

I would like to move on. One of the greatest opportunities this country has for creating enormous wealth is in fish and prawn farming. To put this into perspective, when I served as northern development minister in the government of Queensland in 1984, Dr Joseph Baker, who was head of the Institute of Marine Science, absolutely insisted that this government had to get into prawn and fish farming. Whether he was doing that to relieve the pressure upon the natural resources of the ocean or because, as he argued very stridently, his country needed the income, both those things were conditioning his determination to see this industry open up.

I pay a very great tribute to Dr Joseph Baker, who was appointed to head up Landcare Australia, after he finished up at the Institute of Marine Science. I was very deeply regretful that his time came to an end at Landcare. As a result of his representations to us, we went out and looked for a prawn or fish farm in Australia. The year must have been 1984. In the whole of Australia, we could not find a single prawn or fish farm.

We located one that had gone broke on the wharf in Cairns. It was a pretty primitive sort of an operation. Two little kids' swimming pools were basically all that was there. The gentlemen concerned said he had been bankrupted and released a string of obscenities at both the state and federal governments.

However, after many difficulties and very great cooperation by the then premier, Joh Bjelke‐Petersen, we got the show on the road. We are probably now producing about $200 million in prawn and fish farming in Queensland. Tasmania has been a marvellous success story in this area. Other parts of Australia have got into the game as well.

Where we had been expecting to be doing about $200 million in prawn farming alone in Queensland by 1995, I very much doubt that by 1998 we will even hit $60 million. The reason is that the Greens and the environmental movement have managed to close more farms than we have been able to open. The existing farms have increased production dramatically, and I pay very great tribute to Ervin Vidor, the Sydney builder and construction engineer: Ervin has been a great pioneer, and his farm will now be turning over about $25 million. It is one of the ones that has greatly expanded production, and Ervin has been very much hands on in the whole project. He took 12 years of losses before he turned a profit, and so he is a great Australian who has made a very great contribution to his country.

To put Australia's achievements in this area into perspective, North Queensland—not all of Queensland, but North Queensland alone—has a coastline 10 times greater than that of Thailand. Thailand makes $2.2 thousand million per year in prawn production. As I said previously, we are not even producing $70 million worth of prawn and, in fact, the number of prawn farms operating is going down and not up; and that is a reflection of where Australia is at and of where we are going, and of where other countries are going.

I would say that, at the very least because we have extremely clean water—in fact, except for the coastal belt between Cairns and Townsville, there is hardly any intensive farming taking place along the whole coastline of North Queensland, which is something of the order of 2,000 or 3,000 kilometres long—and because we have the right water temperature, we have absolutely everything that we need for these industries to take place. But they are not taking place.

I must say that native title claims are also playing a very significant role in this. The nature of land ownership by the Aboriginal people of Australia is that they cannot own land but must have some sort of mickey mouse, half‐feudal, half‐communist arrangement that has been imposed upon them against their will. If they were able to own that land privately as freehold title, in the same way that everyone else on earth is able to own it, I am sure that this industry would be exploding throughout all of those areas. In fact, the government operation, the crocodile farm at Edward River, was, when I was minister, arguably the biggest crocodile farm in the entire world and was certainly one of the most successful.

Finally, in the short time that is left to me, the report by GBRMPA on the question of dugong in Queensland, which again is not addressed in this report, is a very shabby document indeed. It is indeed a shabby document because—as I heard six members of parliament, including yourself, Madam Deputy Speaker Kelly, get up in one of the halls of power and say—there is no scientific evidence in this document whatsoever. It reads more like a little pamphlet that you would expect from an undergraduate conservation group at a university: a totally emotional document without any substance behind it. In fact, it is positively—and I cannot but use the word—deceitful.

Let me back up that claim. The document says that dugong numbers have dropped clean in half in the state of Queensland; and then, to substantiate that claim, they use the numbers from the southern half of Queensland and not from the northern half of Queensland. But the vast bulk of dugong is in fact in the Torres Strait, and the numbers in the Torres Strait have doubled. All that happened was that there was a series of droughts, and the dugong moved north.

Dugong have been proven in scientific studies on many occasions to travel 500 or 600 kilometres: one tagged dugong from North Queensland ended up a stone's throw from Sydney. They can travel very great distances. Like every other animal, when they lose their habitat, they move somewhere else where the grass is greener—or where at least the grass exists. What happened was that the dugong living in Southern Queensland—like the rest of Australia—simply showed their enlightenment by moving to Northern Queensland. So the dugong numbers moved north—in this case, to the northern half of the coastline of Queensland. But that was not brought out in the report at all. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Dr Nelson) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 August, on motion by Mr Lieberman:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report on greater autonomy for Torres Strait Islanders and to support the thrust of the report details and, indeed, its recommendations. Firstly, I would like to express my congratulations to the committee chair, the member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) and the members of the committee. I think that we all got on extremely well and had very fruitful discussions. In particular, the committee secretariat—the secretary, Judy Middlebrook; the inquiry secretary, James Catchpole; and also Claressa Surtees and Natalie James—put a great deal of effort and commitment into the inquiry. The report reflects the serious consideration which the committee gave to the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite ironic that we are here debating Torres Strait Islanders: a new deal, a report on greater autonomy for Torres Strait Islanders, at a time when the current government has introduced and has had passed through the House of Representatives its legislation on Wik, which would indeed wind back the rights and the autonomy of indigenous Australians. On the one hand we have a report—indeed, a whole inquiry—talking about giving power, economic and political, to a group of Australians, in this case Torres Strait Islanders, but on the other hand we have a government which is attempting to take away those very rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. The remarks made by the speaker opposite have nothing whatsoever to do with the bill. He is talking about Aboriginal affairs.

—On the point of order, I find it extraordinary that the Wik decision—which arose out of the Mabo decision, which is related to a Torres Strait island—would have nothing to do with this report on Torres Strait Islanders. It is absolutely extraordinary that the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) would argue that this report has nothing to do with Wik. One of the highlights of my participation—
—I didn't know that.
—The member for Kennedy says that he did not know that. He is on the committee and he does not know what the report is about. That perhaps sums up this government's attitude towards the report.
—The member for Grayndler will resume his seat. The member for Kennedy.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, on another point of order: he said that I am on the committee. I was not on the committee when this tour was carried out, and I still do not understand what a visit to Eddie Mabo's grave has got to do with fishing.
—There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for Grayndler.

—There is certainly no point of order because of the membership of the committee. I point out to the member for Kennedy that page 13 of the report says that the `Hon. Bob Katter MP' is a member of the committee. He was in fact on the committee throughout this inquiry.
—I take the point of order.

—I suggest that I won a victory here on the point of order. I only hope that I am as successful in debating the substance of indigenous issues as I have been in debating the procedural point before the House today.

BREAK.PARA: It is very ironic that this debate is taking place at a time when the government's legislation would seek to remove the right to negotiate, which would seek to extinguish native title rights in bucket loads, to quote the Leader of the National Party, the member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who spoke of `bucket loads of extinguishment'. It is a tragedy that that is the case.

I also think it is unfortunate that of the gang of five or six who took the absolutely extremist position on the native title legislation in crossing the floor, three of those are members of this committee and they put their names to a committee report which says that they want a new deal and they want greater autonomy for Torres Strait Islanders. That hypocrisy does need to be exposed.

It was a very difficult inquiry and a difficult issue because, as with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues, there certainly are no simple solutions. When we travelled to the Torres Strait we looked at the massive problems of education, of health, of housing, and I do not doubt the sincerity of people on the committee. We might have had different views as to what the solutions were, but certainly all of us were concerned at lifting the human rights and the economic and social conditions of Torres Strait Islander populations that we visited, whether they be on the islands or on the mainland.

One of the difficulties that we have had with this debate is that due to displacement, due to an economic imperative of Torres Strait Islanders to move from the islands, today there are only approximately 6,000 Torres Strait Islanders living in the island region—they make up about 80 per cent of the population—whereas there are 23,000 Torres Strait Islanders living on the mainland. So one of the difficulties that we had was coping with the different points of view from the Torres Strait Islander people themselves. Many of the people on the islands felt that they, and they alone, should determine the direction of policy for Torres Strait Islanders. Whereas, not surprisingly, the people on the mainland felt that they should have a big say in what occurred in their homelands. That was also a very understandable view.

However, I think the recommendation that the report comes up with strikes an appropriate balance. On the one hand, you have a recommendation for the creation of a new body, the Torres Strait regional assembly, with one representative from each island, and with greater representation, three, from Thursday Island and two from Horn and Prince of Wales. Such an organisation should receive, according to the recommendations, block funding from both the Commonwealth and Queensland governments and, after a few years of operation, should report back to those bodies to see how the new organisation is functioning in terms of political representation and also delivery of services to the Torres Strait Islander people.

I would be surprised if some on the mainland were not disappointed with this recommendation and by the fact that they will not be able to directly participate in the Torres Strait regional assembly. Nonetheless, I think there is no real alternative to put forward, except that they remain within the umbrella ATSIC organisation.

I was particularly concerned that when parliamentarians, or any other group of Australians, have a look at organisations from indigenous people we do not set the bar on the high jump higher than we do for ourselves. It seems to me that in some of the questioning that took place in some of the inquiries that is exactly what we were doing. It seems that there was much assumption that ATSIC was an organisation which did not act properly; but when put up with the facts of funding of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations through the ATSIC regional bodies, we received no real evidence at all that ATSIC funded the organisations anything other than properly.
I want to refer to one of our first hearings which took place in Townsville. We received evidence from a Ms Duell, who stated:

We also looked at the funding issue, and as Jenny has just pointed out, 90 per cent of our organisations are incorporated as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and they service those populations. When we looked at just Torres Strait Islander organisations and just Aboriginal organisations that were funded, we were able to demonstrate to Canberra that they were more than adequately funded. I will give you an example: last year out of non‐capital funding, $400,000 went to Torres Strait Islander organisations and only $20,000 to Aboriginal organisations.

I think that the sort of questioning which took place and the assumptions that ATSIC is not a good organisation were inappropriate in this inquiry. It is true that many of the witnesses before the inquiry did not believe that all truth and light rested with ATSIC, that is not surprising. One of the difficulties Torres Strait Islanders have got is that they are a minority within a very small minority of the Australian population, and that puts them in a difficult position. I think ATSIC needs to ensure that they continue to deal appropriately with the concerns of Torres Strait Islanders.

I think that some of the concerns raised by some of the committee members were not justified. I refer to a hearing, again in Townsville, where it was suggested that somehow Torres Strait Islanders were not represented properly. The member for Capricornia, Mr Marek, asked Mrs Pryor, who was a witness before the committee, some questions:
Mr MAREK —So there are 13 Aboriginals and only seven Torres Strait islanders? Do they all have the same voting rights?
Mrs Pryor —Yes.

Mr MAREK —How can you say that it is fair and equitable representation? We are talking about a group of people here who want greater autonomy—that is understood. Therefore, it must come down to the fact that they are not getting fair and equitable representation. If they are not getting fair and equitable representation, it sounds as though some of the submissions they are putting forward are not getting up. Perhaps it is the fact that they do not have the same amount of voting rights.
Mrs Pryor responded:

But Mr Marek, there are seven regional councillors representing only one‐third of the population. So they do have equitable representation—in fact they are over‐represented for the per capita population

That was what we found in general. That was what we found when we went to Brisbane for the hearings and that was what we found when we went to Cairns for the hearings. We found that in general terms, as a democratic process, the ATSIC elections are extraordinarily successful in achieving a proportional representation outcome in which Torres Strait Islanders do have that direct representation, and I think that remains very important if they are going to have that say.

I want to conclude my comments by referring again to the Mabo decision of some years ago and the follow‐up decision on Wik and to say that I think it is a tragedy that we as a parliament can consider reports such as this and have a unanimous report come before the committee, because essentially it does not cost any money and essentially it is about politics more than economics.

If we are going to be fair dinkum about talking about the rights of indigenous Australians, and in particular Torres Strait Islanders, we do need to talk about those economic rights. They need to talk about fishing, gaining employment and giving them real autonomy over their local conditions. But whilst we continue to have a selfish government which is attempting to take away even the right to negotiate over native title, Torres Strait Islanders—and the indigenous community in general—will not take this report as seriously as they might, because that sort of hypocrisy stands out. That sort of hypocrisy sticks in the throat of every decent Australian who respects human rights and, in particular, the human rights of our original inhabitants—our indigenous peoples.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not want to enter into a debate along the lines that my friend the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) has raised, but I do have to raise a couple of matters in response to what he said. With respect to him, what he has said is a typical `rhetoric without substance' phrase. That phrase was said to me by an Aboriginal gentleman who lived in Cairns. He said, `All of this stuff is rhetoric without substance.' Where does the substance come from?

SPEECH.PARA: I recommend to the honourable member for Grayndler that he read the book Past wrongs: future rights by Michael Warby and then come back into the House and say that everything that he has said still stands. That book challenges the traditional thinking that has totally failed Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. I will read the conclusion of that book because I think it is important to get this message through. It says:

Since the early 1970s, the anti-discrimination model and welfare models have dominated public discussion, and public policy, for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues. They are dangerous ways to present the issues because they focus overwhelming attention on what allegedly is or is not done to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, rather than on their cultural and institutional structures and skills and the incentives generated by public policy. While these models dominate public policy perspectives, policy will continue to be framed ultimately in terms of a passive role for indigenous Australians—with more power to anti-discrimination authorities, more expenditure on programs laboratory labelled "indigenous", despite the patent, and stubborn, lack of response of actual social outcomes to these approaches. Without a fundamental change in approach, the profound, though not unrelieved, failure of public policy in this area will continue.

Cultures—the knowledge, values and informal institutional structures transmitted across generations—have consequences. Cultural content is not a matter of some lifestyle "taste sensation" where one can blithely choose combinations with no effect on basic social outcomes. They are matters which pertain directly to better or worse interaction to the world as it is. It is not possible to achieve industrial‐age life expectancies in an industrial‐age society with hunter‐gatherer notions of asset management, causality and nutrition. Similarly, it is not possible to achieve industrial‐age standards of living with hunter‐gatherer notions of asset management or social organisation. In particular, the choice of communal, inalienable title is the choice of poverty: as the experience of the command economies has shown very clearly.

This is not a matter of cultural obliteration, it is a matter of cultural adaptation and evolution sufficient to achieve the levels of life expectancy, health and standards of living that all agree are minimally acceptable levels of achievement for Australian citizens. This is a process that all cultures have had to go through to achieve (where they have) such standards—for example, freedom from endemic epidemics and high levels of infant mortality is an achievement less than two centuries old in European and European‐descended societies. Indeed, the current life expectancies of indigenous Australians are equivalent to those of the general Australian population in the 1880s and 1890s.

Aboriginal cultures were isolated for millennia from the developing knowledge, institutional development and understanding of other societies. The efforts, sacrifices, sufferings and achievements of generation after generation of the societies of Japan, Northwestern Europe and descendant societies and their adaptors have resulted in the achievement of unheralded mass prosperity and freedom. It is only if we understand the real basis for that success that we can see a way forward for those who do not yet fully share in it. Indigenous Australians cannot fully participate in that achievement unless they also adapt to those understandings and institutional achievements.

The developing thread in public policy of building up an independent, privately owned asset base for indigenous Australians is far more potentially productive than the previous welfarist and anti-discrimination approaches. But only provided such an approach is:
. a basis for building up institutions, and assisting in the reconstruction of a vibrant civil society, genuinely inclusive of indigenous Australians; and
. fostering the cultural adaptation which must occur if indigenous Australians are to gain rightful benefits of participation in Australian and global society.

Cultural (including institutional) adaptations must come from within indigenous societies and communities if they are to succeed. Forced persistence with, for example, communal and inalienable title is not only a basis for progress in improving conditions for indigenous Australians, it will actually retard progress.
It continues, and I wish people would listen to this:
Native title, construed as communal, inalienable and generally partial title, is not the path forward.

That public policy should be based on the principle that race should not matter, except when it does, is a contradiction that cannot stand. It is too subtle a mix for the coarse operation of political processes; its intellectual incoherence not only ensures that it will not achieve its aims, but is a sign of deep lack of seriousness, of lack of genuine concern with consequences, with what actually occurs for real people with real lives to lead.

What policy had not done is to allow Aboriginal peoples to find their own paths to successful adaptation to the benefits and pressures of modern society. It may be that many will fail—achievement without the possibility of failure is an empty concept. Indigenous Australians do not start with an ideal set of cultural supports. But the consequences will be, as much as is practicable in a diverse society subject to the normal processes of happenstance, their own. Which is as it should be.

I find it very difficult to argue with that. I was not going to quote it in full, but, since the honourable member for Grayndler mentioned it, I believe it is necessary. I do recommend the book to people who should read it before they formulate views, which are based frequently on ideology rather than on looking to see how we are going to solve the real problem.

BREAK.PARA: I do not criticise the member for Grayndler. In fact, I enjoyed very much going on that trip with him. He is a person with deep commitment to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people—I have no doubt about that. But let us not get bogged down in the ideology that somehow it is racist and speak of the right to negotiate as some sort of magic common law right. It is not a common law right. It is something that was put in a statute by the previous government and it has been used as a vehicle for extortion which will make very few very rich.

That is the problem. It will not help the people out at Cherbourg, the people I have worked with over 12 years, or the people in central Queensland at Woorabinda and at many other places around Australia. The great majority of the Aboriginal people in this country will get nothing from native title or the right to negotiate.

Turning to the particular matter before the Committee, I felt very privileged to be a part of the inquiry and able to visit the Torres Strait and many islands first‐hand. Obviously, we did not get to visit the full extent of the islands, but we did visit a number of them and saw a number of things.

The first thing that struck me was that there was an incredible potential for ecotourism. I do not mean five‐star hotels springing up out of reclaimed land somewhere, but there is an enormously unused potential. I have a dream for the Islanders, if I can be so patronising as to say this. I want to see them have ultimate political autonomy, not from Australia but as part of a territory of Australia. That is what I believe they want. It is so important, in my view, to provide the paths to give them that. Because that is part of emancipating them from the welfare notion and directing them to the notion that once they build economic autonomy from that will flow political autonomy.

I believe that is possible. It is not going to happen tomorrow or next week. It will take time, but this report does provide a model or direction for that with the recommendation of the Torres Strait Regional Assembly. It is necessary for the Islanders—and they recognise this themselves—to get away from the handout or sit‐down‐money mentality.

As I said in the House the other night, I met with Syd Kyle Little, who was a patrol officer in Arnhem Land for four years in the late 1940s. Talk about someone who knows Aboriginal people well! I am making the distinction between Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders, and it is important to do that. We cannot just lump them in together—that is something I learnt on the trip. We have to distinguish between the two groups, and within the Aboriginal group obviously there are many distinctions. He started Maningrida as a trading post, and it worked really well. The Aborigines would go out and hunt and they would trade. It worked very well until Mr Whitlam and Nugget Coombs came along and said, `From now on you are going to be paid to do nothing.' That was the end of Maningrida; that was the end of their lifestyle.

One day it is going to happen that Aborigines will sue the government for doing that—that is what is going to happen next. That will be the next round of lawsuits following on from the separated children. It will be based on us having changed their lifestyle for the worse by our patronisation, instead of us looking at it realistically and looking at the Australian coast and saying, `Look at the potential for employment there.' We need people to be surveying our coasts. Syd Kyle Little made the suggestion to the then defence minister, Sir James Killen, that we could provide motor bikes. He made the suggestion that there was a real need to have people watching that coast, as there is in the Torres Strait. We should be employing Torres Strait Islanders and Aboriginal people in that respect. There is great potential there.

I was very disappointed to learn on the trip that though Torres Strait Islanders, as part of their natural culture, were market gardeners, there was virtually no evidence of it and yet the fertility of the islands is phenomenal. Then we were told by Queensland government officials, `We have a program up there. We have spent something like $5 million on a program.' I said to them, `Where is it? We saw absolutely no evidence of this.' They were astonished at this. I do not think it has ever been resolved in the material. I do not think we ever did get a resolution of it, but they were taken aback when I said that we saw no evidence of it. That is another example of one thing being said in Brisbane and another thing actually happening on the Islands.

Another lasting image for me was seeing, on Murray Island, an Aboriginal lady with a young child walking underneath a mango tree, both drinking cans of Coke. When a beautiful mango dropped down in front of them they walked straight past it. That is an absolute tragedy. We have to do something about that. But they have to do it too.

We have to provide training. It is important to do that if we are going to build some sort of economic base up there and assist the Islanders and encourage them, because they do a great job for Australia. They are the first line, as it were. Then there is the issue of illegal immigrants, as we found on Saibai recently. I thought Terry Waiai was a terrific bloke for the work he has done on Saibai as chairman there and so forth. We need to encourage the people to be paid to watch that. They need to be trained and to be engaged in watching our coastline to stop the spread of exotic diseases and to address the immigration factor as well. We have to be looking at that, and that gives them a base to work with.

With tourism, there certainly does need to be training for the people. You cannot say, `Yes, we will have tourism,' and expect people to be going in there, untrained, to run it. Obviously they need to be trained and encouraged to take secondary schooling. And they have to come back. The Islanders who have gone to the mainland want to go back, but they have to send their children there and frequently their children do not come back because there is nothing in the way of employment to come back to. So the training is drained out of the island and it is left. Meanwhile we see all of this equipment lying around in a state of disrepair, and more money is spent on buying more equipment while the equipment remains unrepaired. But it is not spent on the training. That is an aspect that really needs consideration.

The potential is there. When I broached this subject with the Islanders they welcomed it. They were keen on it. The Islanders did not like ATSIC, contrary to what the member for Grayndler said. My experience, universally, was that they did not like ATSIC. They would prefer direct funding, bypassing all of the dilutions that occur with the ATSIC models. I would support that totally. Obviously, there are very special cases there with their health problems. They need to get to doctors. They have distance problems. As mainlanders, we have to help in that respect. But the success also has to come from within. It will come from within but we have to encourage tourism and we have to encourage the economic base. From that will flow the political autonomy which will give these people a terrific vision for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some comment on the report, Torres Strait Islanders: a new deal , as presented by the chairman, the member for Indi (Mr Lieberman). I should say at the outset that my support for the 10-point plan of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is well documented and I support it because of the certainty that it will create for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to pick up the remarks made by the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese). The member for Grayndler and I visited the Murray Islands, together with other members of the committee, on 23 October last year. The interesting thing, and the point that I picked up whilst we were there on the Murray Islands was that since the Eddie Mabo decision the people there really felt that they had been let down. Some time after the decision there was a feeling that they had no opportunity to claim land on their own islands. That was a problem and I found that astounding. I found that quite an unusual statement to be made by those people from the eastern islands, the Murray Islands as they are called.

The honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) and the honourable member for Grayndler took time while we were there, because it was only an informal discussion, to visit Eddie Mabo's grave. I am sorry that I did not have the opportunity of getting there but we were busy talking to the people at the council.

In terms of autonomy, there are some parallels there with the Northern Territory because, while the Northern Territory was given some self-determination in 1974, it really was not until 1 July 1978 that more autonomy was bestowed upon the people of the Northern Territory by the Legislative Assembly. Some 20 years later the progress of the Northern Territory is seen to be amazing and today, in the tough economic climate that exists because of reasons known to us all, the territory's economy is on the move in terms of economic development, the pastoral industry and the tourist industry. The level of unemployment is the lowest in the nation.

The Torres Strait over the past few years has been governed through Canberra and dictated to through Queensland, and there have been another 17 organisations in the Torres Strait with overlapping responsibilities.

I ask honourable members to consider the report. Other members have already congratulated the committee secretariat and the people who participated by way of submissions. It was a very good exercise that gave the members of the committee a greater understanding of what the problems were, not only on the mainland for Torres Strait Islanders but also on the islands themselves.
The submissions given to the committee made up the basis of the report—it is a very good report. On page 43, clause 3.26, under the heading `Improving service delivery', it states:
Torres Strait Islanders are critical that policies affecting the Torres Strait region are developed in Brisbane, Cairns or Canberra and have little relevance to the region.
As one commented:

The Torres Strait people are the best qualified ones to speak, as we know and experience the day to day problems inside the Torres Strait. Greater autonomy for the Torres Strait is quite simply a more effective structure in which to address the needs of our people.

I think that sums it up, Madam Deputy Speaker. As I said, the Northern Territory was in much the same boat until 1978, because all the decisions that were being made for and on behalf of the Northern Territory were being made some 3,500 kilometres away. The proof of the pudding is that the Territory certainly has stood out since self‐government.

One could imagine that, with more autonomy in the Torres Strait, the Torres Strait people would have a greater level of expectation for achievement. When you read the report and pick up different comments made by the people who provided submissions, there was confusion about where they should apply for levels of funding—whether it should be through ATSIC, the Commonwealth government or the Queensland government. So more autonomy and, as the report says, a new deal are obviously going to give the people of the Torres Strait better direction.

Of the 25 recommendations in the report, I believe the two most important ones that should be considered relate to the next process of direction. Further discussion still needs to take place between the Commonwealth government and the Queensland government with regard to a process for more autonomy. I believe recommendations 24 and 25 for the way ahead place further emphasis on both governments to really get on with the job and not to let this report and its recommendations gather dust.

The committee put a lot of effort into the report, and people on both the mainland and the islands went to a lot of trouble to provide submissions to the committee. Recommendations 24 and 25 seem to emphasise the fact that the key to success in delivering benefits to Torres Strait Islanders is consultation and negotiation. Recommendation 24 states:

The committee recommends that the Commonwealth government facilitate a process of consultation with relevant State Ministers, Torres Strait Islanders and all other residents of the Torres Strait region to ensure their support before any legislation is introduced into the Commonwealth Parliament to amend the structures of government or administration in the Torres Strait region.

That recommendation itself could take as long as 12 months to get to the stage where legislation was even considered for introduction into the federal parliament. I believe it is very important—and very incumbent upon the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron)—to treat this particular recommendation as being as important as, if not more important than, preceding recommendation 23.

Recommendation 23 deals with the mechanism of how more autonomy can be put in place for the Torres Strait Islanders, but recommendation 24 relates to a future process to ensure that all the people of the Torres Strait, whether they are based on the mainland or in the Torres Strait itself, have some say in the legislative process that is going to be put in place.
Recommendation 25 is of a similar nature but is different. It states:

The committee recommends that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) facilitate a process of consultation with Torres Strait Islanders living on the mainland before any changes are made to the ATSIC structure and arrangements for Torres Strait Islanders living on the mainland.

That process itself could take another six to 12 months. We need to put a mechanism in place through the minister to ensure that ATSIC proceeds to obtain the views of the people living on the mainland.

As you move around the northern part of Australia, there is a train of thought from our Australian indigenous communities which says, `Why do we need the Torres Strait Islanders in our commission when they are really separated from the things that we do?'

The same question is asked by the Torres Strait Islanders. They ask, `Why do we need to be involved with ATSIC and with the Australian Aboriginal indigenous community, when they are different from us?' That particular comment was highlighted on more than one occasion during the course of the inquiry. One could use some indigenous vernacular, but it would not be understood. The point simply is that Aboriginal people were saying that they should be separate and Torres Strait Islander people were saying that they should be separate.

A new deal for the Torres Strait Islanders would certainly give them economic benefits. As the honourable member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) said a few moments ago, the ecotourism potential of the region is outstanding. People in the tourism industry all over the world are looking for new locations that are relatively unspoilt. They do not want five‐star, 16‐storey hotel buildings. They are looking for reasonable, clean accommodation with reasonable transport, access and facilities. They would like to get into parts of the world that are relatively undisturbed. I believe that the Torres Strait area has great potential for ecotourism.

When we move to more autonomy for the Torres Strait Islanders, the Australian community must look at improving, increasing and better defining Australia's security. Many of the Torres Strait Islands abut the south coast of Papua New Guinea. I am told that, when the tide is out, people from Papua New Guinea can almost walk across the flat to Saibai Island, which is very close to New Guinea. Boigu Island, which is a bit further west, is even closer.

The committee visited Saibai Island. I was worried that, without proper security precautions in place, it would be very difficult to police that region through quarantine and customs services. Any initial planning for more autonomy for the Torres Strait must include consideration of the future security of that region. It does not take much imagination to realise that all kinds of nasties could come to Australia because of that close proximity. Once they get to Saibai Island it is only a short trip to the mainland.

As other members have done, I congratulate the secretariat for its hard work in providing the committee with the resources to take submissions throughout the Australian region. With the help of the secretariat, we visited all the Australian states, took submissions from Torres Strait Islanders—of which some 30,000‐odd live on the Australian continent—moved throughout the Torres Strait region, and eventually finalised the report which was tabled in this parliament in August.

The work has been done by the committee, the recommendations are in place, and they must now be evaluated and acted upon by the Commonwealth government, in association with the Queensland government. As the report says, a new deal for Torres Strait Islanders is important. We should move very quickly to implement the recommendations of the report and to give the Torres Strait Islanders a new deal to allow them the capacity to determine their own destiny and to coordinate the development of the region. All we need to do now is to let them get on with the job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Entsch, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly gives me great pleasure to rise on this occasion to speak on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs report on Torres Strait autonomy entitled Torres Strait Islanders: a new deal . The Torres Strait Islands themselves are entirely incorporated within my electorate. I have had the ongoing pleasure of spending a lot of time in the Torres Strait. I have had the pleasure and privilege of being associated with Torres Strait Island families since I was very young, particularly my Uncle Bobby and Aunty Aggi Ware and their children, Robert and Salma, and the late Benny Ware. In doing so, that opportunity has enabled me to very much understand a lot of the culture of the Torres Strait people and to appreciate that culture and to be very supportive of their views and their aspirations.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the sad things that developed in our country was the grouping together of our indigenous peoples as one single group. Initially it was through Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and now it is through ATSIC. I think it is unfortunate that we were not able to separate the two, given that the Aboriginal culture and the Aboriginal people are very different from those of the Torres Strait. I guess, if you wanted to draw comparisons, it would be very similar to suggesting that people of a white Australian background are similar to Eskimos, for example. Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Island people are just totally different in their cultures, in their whole social structure and in the type of people they are. I think it is absolutely important for us to acknowledge that, and this is what this report is going to do. I believe it is the first step in the right direction in ensuring that they are afforded the recognition that they rightfully deserve.

There was very wide consultation throughout the Torres Strait and also on the mainland, given that populations of Torres Strait people have now spread quite significantly throughout the country. We have some 8,000 Torres Strait Islanders still living in their homelands but there are over 20,000 people of Torres Strait Island origin now living throughout mainland Australia. They are spread from Broome and Kununurra through to Perth, Adelaide, Sydney, Melbourne, Tasmania, Canberra and right up the east coast of Australia. So they are very broadly spread out.

One of the things that we found all the way through this process was that they were very much hanging on to their traditions and to their customs. They all had a very strong affiliation with their homelands. It was quite amazing. Interestingly enough, most of them that we spoke to still had very regular contact with people in the Torres Strait and, in fact, were able to associate themselves with particular islands and with particular communities. I think it was really good to see that they are able to maintain that strength of kinship within the Torres Strait community. It just goes to show the strength of the people and their determination to maintain their culture.

One of the things we found there was very significant numbers of levels of government, which meant that there was a lot of money going into the top bureaucratic end of the process. This tended to restrict the amount of money that came out towards the grassroots people. So one of our first recommendations was that:

. . . the Commonwealth Government negotiate the establishment of a joint statutory agency (the `Torres Strait Regional Assembly') with the Queensland Government to represent all residents of the Torres Strait area and to replace the Island Coordinating Council, the Torres Strait Regional Authority and the Torres Shire Council.

The purpose behind this is to try to streamline the process and to maximise the opportunities for funding that goes into the area so that the people on the ground have a better access to a larger pool.

While it is very widely supported, there are some concerns with regard to the amalgamation of the Torres Shire Council. It is something that we need to look at in consultation with the Torres Strait people. One of the good things that has come out of this report is the fact that, all the way through, we have said that nothing will happen here unless there is broad consultation with the Torres Strait people and consensus. It is important that we get that support. There is no point in us, here in Canberra, imposing our views on these people. It is important that what we develop there is something that is totally supported by the Torres Strait people.

I feel that there is still a bit of work to do in that area. There have been ongoing negotiations and consultations with the Torres Strait community. I am very confident that, at the end of the day, we are certainly going to be able to come up with a resolution to this situation that is going to be accepted by the entire community.

One of the other good things that I see here—and again it is a way of recognising the Torres Strait people as a separate identity—is removing the funding from ATSIC so that the new assembly will be able to access funding directly from Canberra and set its own budgets rather than having to rely on being part of the ATSIC process. As I said earlier, this is a very important way of acknowledging the Torres Strait people as totally separate and masters of their own destiny.

One other very interesting thing that came out in the inquiry was the very strong desire by the Torres Strait people to remain as part of Australia. There was no suggestion from the great majority of people that there should be any separation. They are very proud Australians. This was clearly illustrated during the last world war when, with the formation of the Torres Strait First Light Infantry Battalion, almost every single able‐bodied man in the Torres Strait left his island community and enrolled. They spent the entire war in this regiment, for very little remuneration, and were totally committed to serving their country. I must say that it was very much at the expense of the communities that they left behind because only old people, women and children were left to fend for the communities.

I think that the Australian nation certainly owes a debt of gratitude to the commitment of these people. Sadly, there are very few of them left now as time is taking its toll. They certainly did a commendable job for this country. That is reflected now in their children in that they do not want to be separate from Australia but they do want the opportunity of being able to be identified as a truly different group of people.
Some of the other recommendations that I think were very appropriate were those relating to employment opportunities for our Torres Strait people. Recommendation 15 states:

. . . Commonwealth agencies employ Torres Strait and Aboriginal residents in the Torres Strait region, develop cadetships and training programs for these employees with a goal of extending their representation to all levels and in all occupational groups within the agencies.

I think that this recommendation is absolutely critical. For too long we have had a situation where they have basically brought in white experts from the mainland. They have had token islanders there with little training but certainly with a lot of commitment. Generally the whole thing has been run by people that have had very little association with, or knowledge of, Torres Strait.

It is great to see these sorts of recommendations coming in whereby you are going to now be able to get Torres Strait people at all levels of the various agencies so that they will have maximum input and also have the same employment opportunities, the same promotion opportunities and the same training skills as those afforded to anybody else who wants to take a career in these particular agencies. This is a huge step forward in self‐determination for these people.

Recommendation 12 is that a portion of funding that was previously allocated to ATSIC is to be relocated to allow the Torres Strait Island fisheries training project to commence, and that the assembly should envisage the possibility of establishing joint ventures `to ensure that the three prawn fishing licenses allocated to the Torres Strait Islander and Aboriginal inhabitants in the Torres Strait can be used to the benefit of these people'. Torres Strait Islander people, as most would be aware, are sea people. The sea is very much part of their life, and it is important that they should be sharing in the resources and the opportunities in this area. This has been available for some time but, unfortunately, the funding has not been set aside to allow the training of these people to proceed so that they can take their place and harvest some of the benefits from the sea.

BREAK.PARA: I see this as a very important recommendation that will certainly help to enhance their economic base, and also to develop further training skills for our Torres Strait Islander people in very much a culturally appropriate way, appreciating that over very many years there has been a very significant crayfish industry that has been almost exclusively manned by Torres Strait Islander people. We have had beche‐de‐mer; we have trochus; we have pearl shells. All of this has been done predominantly with Torres Strait Islander labour, and so it will be great to see that they will have now the opportunity of taking over some of these projects in their own right and becoming the entrepreneurs.

One of the other things that we recommended was the upgrading of officers, such as monitoring officers, for the various communities. Involved in this are some 30‐odd monitoring officers at the moment, but they are only paid for working on a part‐time basis of one or two hours per day. They are involved in the various communities right at the front line of keeping an eye on immigration, quarantine and a whole range of other issues. It is important that these people be afforded the training and the upgrading of their skills that will allow them to be employed as full‐time responsible officers.

We have seen a lot of problems in recent times throughout the Torres Strait regarding illegal immigration and quarantine problems and also illicit drugs that have been travelling through there. To be able to really get a handle on this, we must continue to draw on the skills and local knowledge of the Torres Strait people and we should also give them the opportunity of having the appropriate skills to be actually driving this whole process rather than to be following along behind it.

Another thing too was appropriate, in that we looked very hard at the needs and the roles of the mainland people. It is very difficult to be able to tie them in to the Torres Strait Regional Authority as such, and so we felt it appropriate that the mainland people continue to be represented through ATSIC—although we have made recommendations that their representation be acknowledged further within the ATSIC bureaucracy and that there be specific Torres Strait liaison officers nominated in the various regions so that they have a better say. There will, of course, be a Torres Strait representative on the Torres Strait Assembly, and that will give the mainlanders a chance to have a say there.

I have to congratulate the secretariat on its work. I think it has been outstanding. It certainly gave us an opportunity to be able to deliver what I believe to be a very good report. I would also like to commend the chairman of our committee, the member for Indi, Lou Lieberman, who has done a wonderful job. He certainly developed a very good understanding of the Torres Strait Islander people in the time that we were involved in this report.

Through the good work of the secretariat, and of course the outstanding work of our chairman, we have been able to deliver something that has been accepted very much by the Torres Strait Islander people. I believe that this is the first step in a very bright and excellent future for our Torres Strait Islander Australians.
Debate (on motion by Mr Causley) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: White Paper on Foreign and Trade Policy

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 August, on motion by Mr Downer:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hanson, Pauline, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the government's foreign and trade policy paper In the national interest . This paper states that advancing the national interest of Australia and the Australian people is the primary goal. It states that the security of the Australian nation, jobs and standard of living of the Australian people are the paramount consideration in the formulation of policy. It also states that the only way to achieve these objectives is through more globalisation, more free trade and more foreign ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: The report does not, however, define in explicit terms what national interest means, nor does it state in clear terms the impact that ever‐increasing globalisation will have on the average Australian. I suspect that the government has confused national interest with international interest. I will demonstrate that the government's policy to internationalise us is flawed and will destroy Australia and the lifestyle of the Australian people.

Australia has endured 25 years of deregulation, economic rationalism and globalism. We have witnessed the disappearance of most of our Australian icons, we are seeing ever‐increasing foreign ownership of business and assets, and yet unemployment, debt, standard of living, happiness and peace of mind continue to deteriorate. We have been internationalised to a very large degree already, yet the problems are increasing, not diminishing. Does the government really expect Australians to believe more deregulation and selling more of our country will fix our problems?

More and more people are waking up and realising that the policies of free trade are helping other countries, not Australia. More and more Australians are seeing that the people they elected are working for the internationalists, not the Australian people. Successive Liberal and Labor governments, including this current group of treacherous self‐seekers, have worked for the interests of just about everyone except the Australian people who elected them and pay them.

The United Nations, in particular, have been outrageously successful in having our government dance to their tune, which in turn is a death march for our own people and our Australian way of life. Certainly, around election time we see each of the parties selling their wares and sucking in voters with the lie of crumbs of short‐term relief, or making what is our right appear as if it is some magical policy they will bestow upon us like a gift, for which we should grovel and be thankful. But all of these things are just the deception of smoke and mirrors meant to hide the movement of the internationalists.

Those who believe globalisation will save us should just look at where it has taken us so far. We have 700,000 children living in families where neither parent has a job; 2½ million people are either unemployed or underemployed, representing 27 per cent of the work force; 3.3 million full‐time jobs have disappeared, or more than one in two full‐time workers have been retrenched, in the last 12 years. Telstra plans to sack another 22,000 workers; the Commonwealth Public Service will sack 27,000 people next year; 60,000 jobs will be shed by the big four banks alone by 2005. The net growth of full‐time jobs in the 1990s has been zero.

The only employment growth has been in part‐time and casual jobs, and those Australians lucky enough to have a full‐time job have to work longer and longer to keep their families' heads above water. The eight‐hour day is a thing of the past. Growth in low skilled and low paid part‐time and casual jobs is a worrying trend. It is not possible to raise a family or pay off a home on such an insecure and paltry income, and irregular and inconsistent work hours make family life very difficult. You can bet that sort of work would not be good enough for the sons and daughters of our politicians and bureaucrats who are responsible for our national decline, but it is forced on the millions of ordinary Australians who elected these charlatans.

By every measure which the average Australian can use to judge success, globalisation is a total disaster. These are the fruits of globalisation, and unless we rid ourselves of this cult‐like obsession with free trade, Australia will cease to exist as an independent sovereign nation. The greatest advocates of free trade in the world, besides the Australian government, are multinational companies. These companies can shift production from one country to another, exploiting the cheapest labour and paying the least tax possible, while charging as much as possible. For example, Nike makes shoes in overseas sweatshops, but Nike shoes are very expensive. This company exploits cheap overseas labour but does not pass the savings on to customers.

Slashing the sugar tariff this year took millions of dollars out of canefarmers' pockets, and out of country Australia, and gave it to the beverage and confectionery industry, which is almost completely foreign owned. Have soft drink, chocolates or sweets come down in price? When Arnotts biscuits was bought out, US owned Campbells said they would employ thousands more people if they were allowed to take it over. The truth is they sacked thousands. Multinational Dupont was paid $60 million by the previous Labor government to remain in Australia, but they recently closed their factory, sacked 180 workers and kept the money.

It is true that globalisation has increased Australian exports. But how much of these exports is produced by foreign owned companies and what benefit does Australia get from such foreign ownership? In the publication, Trade liberalisation: opportunities for Australia, published by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, companies promoted as Australian food producers are, in fact, foreign owned. Australian Meat Holdings is owned by the US giant, ConAgra. Kraft is not Australian owned, and Lactos is French. Other exporters called Australian, but which are in fact foreign owned or partly foreign owned, include Fasco Australia and Olex Cables.

The SPHC Group, which operates Parkroyal, Centra and Travelodge hotels, is foreign owned, as is Dreamworld. The company Bradmill is owned by Sara Lee. Yakka is partly owned by King Gee, which is foreign owned, and Gloweave has been forced overseas. The automotive industry is dominated by four multinationals, and Bosch and VDO are German owned. In fact, of the 40 or so companies cited by the government as successful exporters, around half are foreign owned.

Australia has one of the highest levels of foreign ownership in the world. Estimates range from an ABS figure of 42 per cent of private corporate trading enterprises, to over 65 per cent of big business, which is an AusBuy estimate, and up to 90 per cent of Australian industry, which is the Austand estimate.

We have no easy way of knowing how much of Australia has been sold, nor of determining if individual companies are foreign owned, as the government does not release that information to the public. In 1986 it was possible to get the information from the ABS publication No. 5322, which provided a complete breakdown of foreign ownership and control of Australia's manufacturing industry. Why has it been discontinued?

If foreign ownership is so good why keep the Australian people in the dark about it? This extreme level of foreign ownership should be of great concern to all Australians. The end results are higher unemployment, profit shifting offshore and tax minimisation.

BREAK.PARA: Mr Michael Crouch, a government business representative on the APEC Business Advisory Council, said in a recent article:

I don't think people realise that the overseas tourist can fly here on an overseas owned airline, stay at an overseas owned hotel, go and eat overseas owned food, go and see an overseas made film, and go home again. They can look at the sights, but that doesn't cost anything.
David James in the article, `The good, the bad and the multinational', in the Business Review Weekly of 17 March 1997, made the following statement:

The most important national contribution multinationals make is paying tax. If they do not pay tax, they are, in effect, receiving free benefits from infrastructure and institutional protections . . .

In the Financial Review of 25 October 1995 it was published that Mitsubishi had revenue of $5.1 billion but only made $5 million of net profit. Toyota had revenue of $2 billion but declared a net loss after tax of $26.7 million.

Mr Jim Killaly, an Assistant Commissioner in the Taxation Office, said in the Sydney Morning Herald on 28 October 1996 that in 1993‐94, 60 per cent of multinationals claimed to be in loss and paid no tax, while the great bulk of the remaining 40 per cent claimed to be marginally profitable and paid only a small amount of tax. As the Assistant Commissioner has not retracted his findings in light of the changes made by the federal government to attempt to stem this loss, I can only assume that this pathetic situation is still occurring.
