Again, the Australian people should not be kept in the dark. We need to know how much of Australia has been sold already and what we are getting out of it before we give the government the go ahead to sell the rest.

In this report the government enthusiastically advocates a reduced role for itself in the governing of Australia as we become internationalised. It suggests that as Australia merges into the world economy domestic and foreign policy will merge and democratically elected government will have less control of Australian affairs. This also means that the Australian people will have less say in how this country is run.

Is the role of government, as expressed in this white paper, to be no more than as manager or caretaker in residence working for foreign interests? The Australian people would be horrified at this prospect. The government barely succeeds in hiding its disdain for Australian nationalism, describing it as inward looking regionalism. I will always stand up for the Australian people first and foremost and put their jobs, needs and wishes before anything else.
I have clearly demonstrated that to swallow the nonsense contained in this white paper is sheer and dangerous folly. On page 33 the report says:
Australia cannot depend on others to promote the interests of Australia.

The Australian people cannot even depend on their own government to promote the interests of Australia. At the next election the Australian people will have their first chance to elect representatives who have their best interests at heart and to arrest the decline of this great country.
I would like to conclude with a couple of quotes from Trade liberalisation: opportunities for Australia, published by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. It says:
Trade liberalisation will not solve Australia's economic problems or magically deliver a prosperous future. Trade liberalisation is not the answer for Australia's future . . .

This paper itself recognises the failures but despite this confession still pushes our country to the brink of destruction. If you continue to disbelieve me, just ask anyone in the chicken, timber, pork, sugar or citrus industries or, for that matter, any farmer or BHP worker. Just ask them how they see the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I did not want to interrupt the honourable member for Oxley in her speech because I did not want to interrupt her train of thought, but she used a term which I personally found offensive when she referred collectively to the members of parliament as `treacherous self‐seekers', and I would ask her to withdraw that term.
—Yes, I will withdraw that.
—Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was appalled by the contribution just made by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) on this paper on Australia's foreign and trade policy. Obviously the honourable member neither has read it nor knows the facts. When people deliberately mislead the Australian people, I regard it as a crime against Australia. She is walking out. She does not understand that she is promoting unemployment. She does not understand that the consequences of her policies and her attitudes are to belittle this nation at a time when there is an enormous future for it. Whatever her attitudes might be, I wish she could get her facts right. Reading inaccurate rhetoric here and taking it as gospel is not the way to help Australia through its present problems—and there are problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to get rid of unemployment. I do not want to have policies advocated by the honourable member for Oxley that are going to promote unemployment. I do not want to have Australia in a position where, again, we are going to go back into the world of the last century—and she does not seem to understand. For example, she talked about Australian ownership. I was very grateful to my colleague the member for Page (Mr Causley), who just gave me the figures given only a few weeks ago to the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. Less than three per cent of Australian land is owned by overseas interests.

In other words, she is looking at a number of companies that have been taken over. But she does not understand that not one of us in this room—whether in the gallery or here—if we look back a few generations, would have been other than from outside Australia. Australia has been settled and developed by successive generations of people who have come and made their home here. Of course we have to have reconciliation with those who have been here in earlier migrations—some 50,000 years ago—but we have to look at the consequence of Australia remaining isolated.

Australia is a small economy. Let me just give you one statistic—and I am sorry if the honourable member for Oxley is not prepared to listen to people. It concerns me that, when you try to put the position in perspective, she is not there. She picks her rhetoric, she picks her words, she picks her references, and most of them are wrong. If you go back to the general question of where and how we develop this country, we have to recognise that we have a population of about 18 million. Australia's 18 million people are in a region where those countries of ASEAN have a population of 400 million. Indonesia alone has 200 million people, and Indonesia is only a hop, step and jump from northern Australia. You cannot live in isolation and say that we are going to be forever able to look after ourselves. We are not able to.

Look at the industries such as the wheat industry and the wool industry that those of us in the rural sector represent. We are producing about 80 per cent of the world's wool. We are not a major producer of wool, but we are a major exporter of wool. We are not like the United States, Europe or China. We do not have a domestic market that is sufficient to be able to consume the goods we produce. If we do not produce goods and sell goods overseas, Australia is going to be unable to maintain its living standards. If we look at a narrow base of overseas ownership, overseas investment and overseas trade, Australia is going to find that there will be more unemployment, not more employment; that there will be lower living standards, not better living standards. We will go into the future in a position where there are diabolic consequences for all of us.

I do not want to go back. In fact, it had not been my intention to remark on the comments by the member for Oxley, but so many of them are wrong. She talks about the highest percentage of foreign ownership in the world. Those figures are wrong. She talks about the shifting of Australian ownership offshore. It is true that we are still a country in need of capital. Australia is a developing country. We are fortunate because we are also developed, but if our industries are going to develop we need to get funds from overseas. We do not have sufficient resources.

Last night, a few of my colleagues and I were talking with some people from Mount Isa Mines. If they are going to develop new mines here, they have to invest large sums of money—billions of dollars. If they invest those sums of money, they generate employment, both in the construction phase and in the operating stage, and they export minerals. The product of exporting minerals is that wealth comes back into Australia.

The member for Oxley made a great deal of the amount of money that is paid in taxes by overseas companies, but she did not understand that, although they may not be operating at a profit on their balance sheets, there are several ways in which companies are taxed. Firstly, they are taxed through their employees—and they employ many thousands of Australians. Secondly, they pay indirect taxes on fuel, sales and so on. Thirdly, their profits are assessed against the overall balance sheet of whichever country they come from. If it is felt that they are moving profits offshore, and those profits are consequently to be taxed in another country, they are assessed as being taxable in Australia.

It worries me greatly that there are so many errors in what the member for Oxley said. It relates very much to the policy statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), In the national interest. Australia should recognise that we need to combine our relationship with other countries and our need for overseas investment with the requirement that we develop our resources in land, people, and minerals. If we can do that, we will have a partnership for the future. We cannot close the shutters and still operate as a viable nation in the way which most Australians would request. We have to be prepared to have investments from overseas and for Australia to play a part in the world.

The two prime emphases within the paper In the national interest—and I think properly so—are on globalisation and the effect it is having on us, and the continuing economic rise of Asia. Why are they the most significant aspects of where we are going? If the honourable member for Oxley had said that she was worried about the Hollywoodisation of Australia, I would have agreed with her. In many ways, in a cultural sense, we are subject to too much of an impression from the dominant powers in the media world.

Regrettably, the images from the United States, and from Hollywood in particular, have tended to dominate the thinking of many of our young people in a social sense. That is not something over which anybody is able to exercise total control. Indeed, governments of both persuasions, through broadcasting and television policy, have introduced requirements about Australian content, the way in which Australian idiom is developed, and how we can present an Australian version of things. That really is what this is all about.
Indeed, had the honourable member for Oxley read this white paper, she would have seen that, in paragraph 10, it says:

Australians should have confidence in Australia's capacity to shape its future. Australia brings many economic, strategic and cultural strengths to the pursuit of its foreign and trade policy objectives.
Further on, in paragraph 14, it says:
Being confident about Australia's future does not mean being complacent. Australia cannot rest on its strengths.

I point out to the member for Oxley that there is nothing in this paper which says that domestic and foreign policy objectives are going to be merged. Today, we are all more aware of foreign policy issues. We realise that Australia cannot be an island unto itself. At a time of globalisation, we have to try to influence those in our region.

There are a number of areas in which we can influence them. We can influence them by promoting economic growth in their countries. On other occasions, I have heard remarks made against Australian aid by the honourable member for Oxley. One of the reasons we have an aid program is to try to ensure economic and political stability. If there is economic growth and people see that they have a capacity within their country to achieve the same living standards as others, they are not going to fight wars. They are not going to fight with each other. They are going to be busy trying to improve their living standards.

However, we have to try to promote democratic institutions. We are all concerned about the degree to which, in our region, there are a number of autocratic governments where, regrettably, patronage and corruption are endemic. We have to try to influence them away from that. One of the reasons why I strongly support financial help being given to Indonesia, to Thailand and, prospectively, to a number of other countries in the Asian region is that the IMF, which provides these packages, is setting down conditions of what we call good governance.

While `good governance' might not necessarily be an ideal form of words, what it means is that you are promoting responsibility in government, where you can get rid of some of those elements of corruption, you can get rid of some of the elements of patronage, and you can promote the essence of democracy. The big advantage of democracy, for all the problems that are in it, is that it does allow for succession. I think we are all aware that there is concern about the succession in Indonesia and in a number of countries in our region. It is a product of a democratic process in the Philippines, but there is a worry about the capability and the characteristics of the next government in the Philippines. Even with a democracy, there is not a certainty of what the next government will do.

The IMF conditions are setting down ground rules which, hopefully, help to get rid of those aspects of governance that Australia deplores in the countries in our region. Human rights are a very important product of it. The white paper is not saying that you do not worry about those things. What it is saying is that, if you act as a responsible citizen, you have a capacity to influence those countries in a way towards the practices which we in Australia believe most desirable.

If we do not do that, the downside is that we have an unstable region. We have a circumstance where, for years, Australia has had to defend other countries against what we saw as an encroachment on the principles to which we adhere. We do not want that in our part of the world. It is for that reason that I very strongly support what Australia is doing in Bougainville at the moment. It is a very difficult situation. It is a product of the foreign policy white paper objectives of being a good international citizen.

The second most profound influence on Australia that the white paper has identified is the continuing economic rise of Asia. Again, that is an aspect of the interrelationship between our economy and the world that is terribly important to us. People do not seem to understand that three-quarters of Australian exports—minerals, manufactured goods, agricultural produce—are sold into Asia. If we cannot maintain stability in that region, if we cannot encourage economic growth there, we are going to find that our exports are prejudiced. If we do not get that export income, we cannot fund infrastructure, we cannot fund schools, we cannot fund hospitals, and we cannot fund all the services that people rely on. The important part about being a good citizen internationally is not that you are just helping others but that you are helping yourself. That is really the basic philosophy of this report.

If we help others—if you can avoid the situation we had in World War II when Japan threatened us, if you can avoid the instability that emerged during the Malaysian campaign and the threats that many of us believed to be there during the war in South Vietnam—we are going to ensure that we have stability. We are not going to have our soldiers fighting overseas but we are going to have them serving on peacekeeping missions or on truce keeping missions, as is the purpose in Bougainville at the moment. We are going to have them serving in a way which prevents the threats to Australia. This document looks at both the economic side of things and the security side of things.

I wanted to briefly mention that in the time available to me because I think it has a few very important elements. It identifies that the government strategy for advancing Australia's security interests is a strong national defence capability. While I was minister for defence and in other roles I have taken over the years, I have always held that if you have a strong national defence capability it should be strong enough that you never have to use it. If you have a good defence capability—if it is strong enough, professional enough and technologically advanced enough—you never have to use that defence force. People know that, if they are going to attack you, they are going to suffer. That is one of the reasons I very strongly endorse the actions that the Howard government has taken to ensure that we do play a responsible role internationally in peacekeeping forces. We have done that, and we are doing that. I think it is very important.

The second government strategy in advancing Australia's security interests is the alliance relationship with the United States. The Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade had a two-day seminar recently on our ANZUS relationship. Some would say it is no longer relevant. The point about our relationship with the United States is that the United States is so dominant in world affairs, it is the only world superpower, and it is important we keep it interested in our region. It does not mean we are dependent on it, but it means we work with it.

I can assure you that many ministers, including the present ones, do not necessarily come along and kowtow when America says they want to do something. In fact, we oppose them on many issues. We try and direct them to the way we would wish. But they are powerful allies and a very important factor in our region and, significantly, will be in the future. That is why I believe our ANZUS relationship is important.

The next priority relates to expanding Australia's bilateral, regional and multilateral security links. This government has done a wonderful job. For that reason and because the paper itself sets out a framework for identifying our priorities in foreign policy, this is a very commendable paper. I commend the government for having produced it. It does not answer all the problems. It is a moveable, flexible document and one which I strongly support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was greatly interested in the speech by the member for New England (Mr Sinclair) because he encapsulated the position of the government on particularly its regional arrangements. He makes the observation on the two rescue operational packages—the first in Thailand and the second one for Indonesia—that those are in the national interest of Australia. I, for one, would like to know the details of our participation in them, as I have asked before, given that there are a number of other issues that relate very strongly to Australia's participation. There was no statement made by either the foreign minister or the Treasurer as to Australia's involvement, particularly in the Thai baht bail‐out.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that the right honourable member has said is that by being good citizens we can encourage stability and good relations within our region. The difficulty is that the economic crisis that has faced South‐East Asia, and now is facing North‐East Asia, is to some extent perhaps the consequence of Australia and other nations not taking a strident enough stance on corruption and some of the economic skewings in their own nations.

For instance, one would have assumed that the elements that were responsible for the collapse of the Thai baht were well‐known to the people who are responsible for advising the government on affairs in Thailand, whether they are from the Australian embassy in Thailand or the Thai desk at the Department of Foreign Affairs. One would have assumed that these problems were sufficiently well‐known for Australia to have taken a more strident stance in relation to the problems of dealing with a nation with a thoroughly corrupt system, based as it was on a system of patronage. As we know now from the aftermath of the Thai baht bail‐out, when the finance companies that had participated in the real estate boom—particularly in the Thai capital—collapsed, many of the people in the cabinet or in the Prime Minister's own party were in the list of names associated with those finance companies that had fallen over, leading to a substantial conflict of interest.

The situation is that the countries in our region that have most benefited from the globalisation of the world economy are Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines and Indonesia. Yet, at the same time, the governments of those countries are very reluctant indeed to adopt what most would consider to be the basic tenets of globalised economies such as open trade and a hands‐off approach to the day‐to‐day running of the economy or the day‐to‐day market activity.

Of course, we have seen in more recent times some quite extraordinary statements from the Prime Minister of Malaysia on the collapse of the ringgit and economic problems there. The statements, with the exception of one statement made by the Prime Minister while he was in the United Kingdom, in my view were not answered by our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer). He in fact said that he had been persuaded by other leaders in the region to say nothing. I would have thought that the statements made by Prime Minister Mahathir, particularly in relation to what he considered to be a Jewish conspiracy to bring down his country's economy, were sufficiently bizarre to deserve a strident response.

The right honourable member for New England mentioned the 1930s and security problems then. Had, for instance, some of the leaders of nations in Europe during the 1930s taken a more strident approach to the problems that were being encountered by some of the citizens of Germany and other countries, they would probably have been able to avoid some of the consequences of the Second World War—a war that saw the deaths of a large number of people.

There is a counterargument to the argument of the right honourable member for New England: yes, we should engage in the region and we should also encourage as much trade as possible with our neighbours. But, at the same time, we should not be put in the position where we are in essence appeasing some of the more unpleasant and, in some cases, unacceptable facets of the government policies of the countries that we are talking about. To expand on that a little in relation to Indonesia, from what is now an historical perspective, there are still very substantial problems in relation to East Timor and also, of course, to solving what is now less of a mystery and more of a straight allegation of murder with regard to the deaths of the Australian journalists in Balibo in 1975.

I am not sure there would be many countries around the world that would have taken such a tame stance, in my view, as Australia has done over the intervening period of time. I must say that the response of the Minister for Foreign Affairs to my question during the last session was extraordinary. He in effect said that, because the Indonesians have essentially said that the case is closed, we say the same.

Here we are in a position where, presumably, the Australian government is now negotiating its role in an international bail‐out of the Indonesian economy. I would have thought that was precisely the time that Australia could use what would be an enhanced capacity to get concessions from the Indonesian government to find out exactly what happened: whether the allegations that those journalists were murdered by the Indonesian army are true; and, if they are true, whether the Indonesian government is going to do anything about bringing the people responsible to justice.

I also say that the whole of that period since 1975 and Australia's participation in it is a national disgrace. We have appeased the ruling regime in Indonesia at the cost of many lives of people who are East Timorese. One could say that that is not strictly an Australian problem; but, at the same time, Australia participates in a number of areas where it takes a view on human rights.

I would have thought that, given we have been strident in other places on human rights, it would be an easy thing for people to say to us, `Hang on a second! In your own backyard there has been wholesale murder of people in a way that is unacceptable for obvious reasons, but in a way that you have been almost prepared to tolerate, because of your lack of opposition or the failure to take sufficiently strident action to try to prevent these things from taking place any longer.' Not only have we allowed it to take place but we also financially contribute, and that is obviously another source of criticism for Australia where East Timor is an issue.

If I might, I will dwell on another, perhaps more localised aspect in relation to the application of foreign policy; but firstly I would say it is good that we do actually have a written statement of Australia's foreign policy: it is the first time for a very long time that Australia has had a white paper on foreign policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only one.
—It might well be the only one; I am not sure. The corporate memory—
—It was the only one.
—You were born in the 1930s, and you perhaps have a longer memory than mine. I want to speak on the necessity of establishing full embassy representation by Australia—
—Thank you!
—We are just going on from the debate yesterday.
—I will return that compliment when it is my turn!

—Yes, I am sure you will. I did say then that you looked a lot younger. I would just say that it is absolutely critical that Australia establishes a full embassy representation in Zagreb, Croatia: the need is increasing rather than decreasing. This government said that financial restraint prevents it from following that course at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the need for fiscal responsibility but I emphasise that the government has certain obligations that it should meet in this matter. The three most important obligations are to the development and enhancement of trade with Croatia and throughout the region; to service provision for Croatians, many of whom have strong family and business links to Australia; and to the estimated 10,000 Australian citizens living in Croatia—and also, I might say, to people in Bosnia and Herzegovina who find it difficult to go to either Vienna or Belgrade to obtain adequate embassy services.

I believe that the message we now send, by virtue of the level of existing foreign mission representation, is that our relationship with Croatia—from which one of the largest ethnic communities in Australia is drawn—is not as important as our relationship with Nepal, Kazakhstan, or Trinidad and Tobago. If we have to have cutbacks, I would have thought of Trinidad and Tobago as being areas where we could cut back, surely—unless of course they are places where people like to go to work because they are such a wonderful part of the world.

I am not entirely sure why we need to have a mission in Nepal. I can understand the need for a presence in the central Asian republics; however, I am still not convinced the Kazakhstan mission is as important as having one in Zagreb, Croatia.
I am going to move a motion in the House calling on the government to remedy this situation—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you should declare your special interest.

—I am the chairman of the Australia‐Croatia parliamentary friendship group, but I have never made a secret of that. I am saying that, as far as our relationship with that country is concerned, I would have thought it was absolutely critical. We were, for instance, one of the first nations outside of the European Community to recognise the independence of Croatia and its declaration of sovereignty. Also, we are one of the few countries that have a large diaspora of former Croatian people and their descendants yet we do not have an embassy in Zagreb, in Croatia.

SPEECH.PARA: People talk about eastern Europe, but in actual fact Croatia's position relates it to central Europe. Given the importance of central Europe, given the fact that the Adriatic is going to become a much more important area for trade with Europe, I would have thought that having an embassy in Zagreb is very important.

Those who have been to the region would know that Vienna is 400 kilometres away. It is a long way to go and it involves a fair amount of inconvenience. The consular days service that is provided in Zagreb is, in my view, insufficient. Ministers in the Croatian government have mentioned during discussions in recent times, in relation to visa applications, et cetera, that that has been a problem in the past.

There is a number of other areas that Australia ought to be conscious of. My time is running out but I want to say that there is a need for us to recognise another strong competitor in our region—I am talking about the Asia‐Pacific region; I come from the Indian Ocean side of this nation—and that is the South American continent. When I attended the Asia‐Pacific parliamentary forum in Vancouver in January, I was struck by the strong interest of South American countries, particularly Peru. It is not lost on them that this region has a large market demand. They can see opportunities for them to make inroads into the region.

Countries like Peru and Brazil have, for instance, large Japanese communities; that gives them special relationships with Japan, the country with which we have the largest trading relationship in our region. So this, in my view, is critical. We often, perhaps, are more obsessed with other areas in the Asia‐Pacific region, but I point out the importance of Australia taking a much greater interest in the thrust of the South American nations into looking towards their west, into the Asia‐Pacific region, as opposed perhaps to looking eastwards towards Europe and Africa.

I want to reiterate the point I raised at the beginning, that there is, in my view, a very strong need for us to recognise the important role Australia can play in opposing the sorts of things that have distorted the economies in our region, provoking these most recent economic crises. We can say, I think in good faith, when we are dealing with our neighbours' leaders, that in the end the further globalisation of the world economy, and of the regional economies, is going to depend very strongly on those nations becoming as open and as little corrupt as possible. It seems to me to be self‐serving when we are, in essence, giving comfort to people who are operating corrupt and, in some instances, violent and discriminatory regimes, that we will continue trading under those circumstances without the changes becoming necessary.

The right honourable member mentioned the IMF rescue package. My view is that had the Thai baht bailout not been promoted so strongly by Japan, which had the greatest interest in this—Japan is holding, I think, something like half of the Thai national debt—then possibly the bailout would not have occurred and we would not have seen any changes. Already we are seeing manifestations of the changes in Thailand appearing on the streets in Bangkok.

Given the number of military governments that have occurred in Thailand since the 1930s—I think it is about the same number as the number of constitutions they have had—I would have thought that it may even be promoting instability by the rapid implementation of these changes, rather than a more gradual one, which might have been the case had Australia taken a much more strident position along with other nations in the first place.

It is interesting to note that Dr Greenspan, Chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of the United States, was reluctant to see the United States participate in that rescue. One of the reasons was because, as he said, they had insufficient economic data from which to make what he considered to be a rational decision.

We believe we are perhaps operating more smartly than Alan Greenspan because we are not even prepared to debate the issue in the parliament. Neither of the ministers responsible has made a statement in relation to the matter, and I think that is a disgrace. We were told that parliamentary standards were going to be raised. In the particular instance of the $1.4 billion that has been committed—whether or not it has actually been expended, it has been committed—the taxpayers want to know exactly how, why and what is happening with those arrangements.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor, Bill, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second occasion this week that I have closely followed a speech by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). I do not want to take up too much time in terms of the member for Oxley because, in my view, nationally she is irrelevant. But, that said, what she said here this morning when she used such words in relation to this white paper as `nonsensical' or `nonsense', when she used the word `treachery' and when she talked about death marches and international masters, emphasises to me—and I hope to the Australian population at large—that, first of all, she does not know what she is talking about in general and that, specifically in relation to this report, I doubt that she has even read the white paper.

SPEECH.PARA: That said, I support everything that the right honourable gentleman from New England (Mr Sinclair) had to say on this. I only wish that the media and other people would not generate stories in terms of the member for Oxley which bear little or no resemblance to the truth, because a lot of what she says is, quite candidly, untrue.

The government is well aware of the need for Australia to consider how its national interests can be pursued in the long term. Last year it commissioned a white paper on foreign and trade policy, which is the first comprehensive vision statement on Australia's foreign affairs and trade. As tabled, it identifies Australia's long‐term interests, it examines the international environment in which Australia will pursue these interests in the future and it recommends appropriate strategies for their advancement. Again, as the right honourable gentleman from New England pointed out, not everything in this white paper should be regarded in a biblical sense. Nevertheless, it is a good start to outlining a strategy for the first time.

Let me say at the outset that the government sees Australia in the 21st century as a cooperative, economically competitive and secure nation, comprehensively engaged with the East Asian region, at the same time maintaining and developing links with countries beyond this region. We have paid particular attention to bilateral relationships because we take the view that multilateral institutions, whether regional or global, will always be far more effective if the countries within them have confident and strong bilateral ties. Australia's highest unambiguous foreign policy priority is, therefore, a closer engagement with Asia. Our determination to make this priority a practical reality was clear from our first day in office, in March last year.

The government has continually strengthened and revitalised Australia's bilateral relationships throughout the region in a comprehensive, practical and focused way. However, an Australia‐first policy does not mean Asia only. On the contrary, the Howard government understands that it is not enough to focus on our region alone. We realise that economic interests and our security can be tied up with events well beyond our immediate region and in which there are important historical and geographic dimensions.

In the very short time available to me today I want to explore briefly four important aspects of Australia's foreign policy and those are: Australia's commitment to the region; the enhancement of Australia's security, especially in the context of developments in the Asia‐Pacific region; Australia's broader global links; and, finally, the government's principled approach to human rights and humanitarian issues.

Looking first at Australia's commitment to the region, our approach of making closer engagement with the region our highest foreign policy priority is not new with Australian governments from either side of the political fence acknowledging the centrality of Asia to Australia's national interest in the post World War II era. Dramatic economic and political change throughout east Asia over the past 10 to 15 years has made a strengthened Australian engagement with Asia even more imperative.

The Asia‐Pacific region demonstrably is the vital sphere of our economic and strategic interests with almost two-thirds of our exports going to APEC countries and a growing percentage of these in manufactured products and skilled services, with half of Australia's total foreign direct investment going to APEC countries, and with nine of our top 10 trading partners now located in that region.

The defining dynamic continues to be strong economic growth. Despite what has happened in Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand over recent weeks, World Bank predictions have east Asia growing at over seven per cent a year to the year 2004, and that is 2½ times faster than the rest of the world. By 2020, four of the world's 10 largest economies are likely to be in Asia—Japan, China, Korea and India. Indonesia could possibly be near the top in the next group of 10 countries, which might include Thailand, despite what has happened recently, and Australia. Over the same period Asia's share of the world gross domestic product will increase, possibly to about 35 per cent, up from about 28 per cent as it is now.

For Australia the opportunities and challenge are therefore immense. Sustained growth in east Asia and the opportunities that it gives rise to will only be possible so long as the barriers to the movement of goods, of capital and of ideas, continue to fall, and so long as governments continue on the path of reform and deregulation.

In meeting these challenges the government's overriding goal is to deliver practical outcomes. I believe we have made a very solid start and I want to outline some of the highlights. At the bilateral level we built on the important initial meeting with Dr Mahathir by delivering a new trade agreement with Malaysia last year. That agreement will bring, over time, greater access for Australian producers and benefits to Australian consumers.

At the Australia‐Indonesia Ministerial Forum in Jakarta last year, the Australia Indonesia Development Area, AIDA, was announced. This represents a significant milestone in our bilateral relationship with Indonesia. It is the first such subregional agreement between Australia and an ASEAN country.

The government has also reached a historic maritime boundaries agreement of treaty status with Indonesia which concluded a quarter century process of negotiations. The result is that individuals and companies on both sides of the boundary will proceed with maritime activities on the seabed and in the water column with certainty and security. This was signed by our foreign minister and by Ali Alatas in Perth in March of this year. As chairman of the Joint Committee on Treaties I will be reporting on this treaty to parliament on Monday week.

The government signed a significant new trade agreement with Taiwan last year worth $30 million in overall terms across the spectrum of Australian exports. The government also concluded a single aviation market arrangement with New Zealand, overturning the damage—and it was damage—caused by the previous government's unilateral repudiation of that agreement.

We have also been working closely with the PNG government as recently as the last few days to ensure that Australia's aid program increasingly delivers real benefits for the people of that country and to encourage PNG, in the medium to longer term, to meet the criteria of the World Bank and IMF programs.

BREAK.PARA: In terms of Australia's security, the second fundamental aspect of this government's foreign policy, we have taken steps to improve Australia's security and the strategic environment in which we pursue our interests. We have specifically set out to help in the development of a regional security environment which forestalls resort to force in international disputes, which prevents proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, and which encourages cooperation to enhance the security of the region as a whole.

At the bilateral level, there is a growing acceptance that strong, confident relationships provide the underpinning for regional stability and effective multilateral activity. Australia has been doing this through practical bilateralism in the Asia‐Pacific area and, as the right honourable member for New England said, the government sees its alliance with the United States in that same light. Indeed, the US presence in the Asia‐Pacific and its alliances with key partners are major elements of the region's current stability. In addition to these linkages based on formal arrangements, Australia has a range of other strong and growing bilateral defence and security ties with South‐East Asian countries—and I do not have time to go into that in detail.

At the regional level, the three‐year‐old ASEAN regional forum, the ARF, is characterised by minimal institutionalisation and consensus decision making. The second stage of the ARF's activities, in terms of preventative diplomacy, is already showing good potential. At the third ARF meeting in July last year, for example, the Indonesian foreign minister, Ali Alatas, used his good offices as chairman to convey ARF members' concerns about the situation and the difficulties in Burma, or Myanmar, to the Burmese foreign minister. In terms of the multilateral dimension, Australia is strongly committed to working to rid the world of antipersonnel landmines—and we heard a lot about that earlier in the week.

The third key aspect of this government's foreign policy has been to enhance Australia's broader global links. The government regards our links with other countries beyond the region as important and appreciating assets. For example, there was revitalisation of Australia's relationship with France after the difficulties of the testing in the Pacific; political military talks with Germany were launched last year; and, beyond Europe, the government held the inaugural meeting between Australia and the Rio group in South America last year as a preparatory step to closer trade, aviation and communication links between the two countries.

The fourth aspect is, very importantly, humanitarian issues. I am sure my colleague the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), Chairman of the Human Rights Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, who is sitting alongside me, will agree that a fourth pillar of Australia's approach to its international relationships is a focus on humane and principled foreign policy. We are vitally concerned with upholding internationally recognised standards of human rights and with looking for practical ways to enhance individual dignity and freedom and to promote democracy internationally. We have done a number of things in terms of the International Red Cross and Bougainville—which, again, the right honourable member for New England referred to, and I will not go into those things.

Let me finish by saying that a strong commitment to concrete results and initiatives has been the touchstone of the government's foreign policy to date. That is now reflected in a strategic sense in this white paper. However, we are not resting on our laurels and the task ahead is not only to follow up these directions but to shape Australia's foreign policy in the long term, and this white paper gives us the genesis of that strategy.

As a government, we understand that the success of Australia's foreign policy depends on our domestic economic performance and, to that end, the government's commitment to fiscal discipline and our determination to reform the labour market and the waterfront will have a direct impact on Australia's international competitiveness and our long‐term prosperity and priorities.

Indeed, it is with pleasure that I support this white paper. I commend the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), in particular, for his initiative. I know personally some of the members of that review group, and I am sure they will not mind if I specifically refer to my old friend and long‐term naval colleague Admiral Mike Hudson, who I know played a very important part in developing this white paper. I congratulate him, I congratulate the group collectively and I commend the white paper to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne, Chris, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The fundamental principle which defines good government is the capacity to act at all times in the interest of the nation in matters of domestic and foreign policy. The coalition government has embraced this concept in all aspects of government. As distinct from the former Labor government, the coalition will not, in circumstances where the principal interests of the nation are not catered for or held paramount, be held ransom to the demands of publicly militant minorities. Responsible, competent government listens to the concerns of each member of the community but, ultimately, determines policy by asking: is this in the national interest? Will this decision benefit a majority of Australians? Will this lend itself to a better Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: In its term of government, the Labor Party attempted to sabotage this process through campaigns of polarisation, laced with tired and stale arguments. The Labor Party window‐dresses these arguments by loosely using the word `vision' and it expects the electorate to buy it. I give the electorate more credit than that. This federal government is in a coalition with the Australian people, using the guiding principle of the national interest as a beacon for a shared vision at the dawn of an exciting century.

It is a priority of this government to prepare Australia for the next century. In making these preparations, we acknowledge that sentimentality is not a luxury we can afford or enjoy. We are part of an international community which continues to mature and evolve. Sentimental politics and policy belong to organisations such as the One Nation Party, and not to a responsible progressive government.

Internationally, this evolution includes increasingly competitive trading markets, a combination of both solid and fragile international relationships, technological advancements of an almost incomprehensible dimension, and a moral and commercial need for all countries to enjoy economic prosperity. Domestically, our population is healthier and is living longer, and our young have opportunities not dreamed of a generation ago, and yet are faced with challenges and pressures which are particular to their time.

As we move towards vital economic and foreign policy reforms in preparation for the next century, there exists a dual responsibility, for we also have a responsibility to ensure that the elderly, the poor and the young are not left to fend for themselves. That would only serve to widen the social divisions which this nation has worked hard to close. It would not be in the national interest.

The white paper, In the national interest, implicitly acknowledges that exports earned this country over $100 billion last financial year alone. The white paper demonstrates that this government recognises that hundreds of thousands of Australian families rely on our lucrative and expanding export industry. Over 345,000 Australian jobs are attached to our export market to Japan alone. In the agricultural sector, around 80 per cent of our product is exported to international markets. Of this, approximately 56 per cent of our total agricultural exports are marketed in APEC countries alone. It is quite clear that the benefits of trade liberalisation are not confined to or restricted by geographical boundaries within our nation.

Among other issues, the white paper is also about protecting the jobs associated with our export industry through good policy and creating additional export oriented jobs for the future. Trade liberalisation ultimately means more jobs for Australians. The white paper acknowledges that Australia must become more competitive in manufacturing and the production of goods and services. The presence of tariffs, while often unavoidable, retards our competitive potential. Australia's motor vehicle industry and textile, clothing and footwear industries recognise this fact and, to their credit, are making the appropriate reforms to their operations, with the support, encouragement and continued assistance of this government.

However, this document is far more comprehensive than merely confining itself to the fiscal advantages of a foreign policy appropriate to our times. Australia has an opportunity—and perhaps a responsibility—to play a vital role in international affairs, particularly in our own region. Our traditionally strong relationships with Europe and the United States, coupled with our geographic location and developing bonds with our Asian neighbours, suggests that Australia has the potential to be an international power of significant influence.

Understanding and preaching the concept of globalisation will be a preliminary and key element to this process if Australia is to fulfil its ultimate potential. Globalisation, underpinned by the communications revolution, is not a new phenomenon, nor is it a trendy buzz word. Globalisation is primarily characterised by technological advancements, population mobility and trade liberalisation. Globalisation does not threaten national independence, nor does it foster an unhealthy culture of international interdependence. The theory of globalisation recognises that each nation will benefit by embracing strong and compatible relationships with other nations.

The Australian government's response to the current emergency in Papua New Guinea, for example, is a necessary humanitarian obligation. However, it also recognises, although less importantly, that we have an interest in that nation's prosperity. In its most fundamental sense, globalisation rejects an inward, introspective approach to foreign policy.

The former Labor government boasted that they understood the mechanics and relevance of globalisation and bilateral relationships. It was a curious boast, particularly when one recalls the obvious and predictable damage caused by the former Prime Minister's famous `recalcitrant' accusation against the Prime Minister of Malaysia.

Australia's potential as a nation of constructive, international influence is best illustrated in the context of our relationships with the United States and Japan. In recent history, Australia has persuaded the United States to abandon several policy decisions which related to the Pacific region. More specifically, the separate threats from the United States that China's most favoured nation status and Indonesia's developing nation concessions were to be contingent on their respective human rights records were confrontations that were avoided due to Australian influence.

The appointment of Mr Andrew Peacock, a former distinguished member of this House, as Australia's ambassador to the United States was both timely and appropriate. An acknowledged authority on American foreign policy, Mr Peacock will cultivate stronger and more respected bonds between the two nations.

While our imports from the US have continued to grow at a steady rate over the last decade, the same cannot be said of our export relationship with this market. The value of our exports to the US has oscillated between stagnant and prosperous over the same period of time. It would be simple to provide a cursory explanation for this by referring to the barriers surrounding our agricultural trading relationship with the US. However, to do so would be quite unfair. The primary factor in Australia's substantial trade deficit with the US is the relatively low level of complementarity between their import needs and our product export abilities. This is not to say that we cannot meet the import needs of the US.

The coalition government is committed to strengthening its political and commercial relationships with our Asian neighbours. However, in doing so, we cannot neglect our traditional relationships with the United States and Europe. Indeed, finding our niche in these lucrative markets is the challenge that this nation and this government face. It is a challenge which requires a lateral approach. In identifying and prioritising Australia's contemporary and prospective foreign and trade policies, the white paper encourages such an approach.

In this age of possibility, Australia has a unique opportunity to broker a trilateral understanding between our nation, the United States and Japan. It would be an opportunity to incorporate our joint aspirations of establishing and maintaining positive relationships with both our Asian neighbours and the United States.

Australia's strong trading relationship with Japan is well documented, but our relationship extends beyond this limiting calculation. Buoyed and nurtured by a thriving Japanese tourist industry in this country, Australia and Japan have developed a mutual respect and comprehension of each other's culture and political and mercantile structures.

Despite the lingual and cultural differences, Australia and Japan are closely aligned in terms of economic and political values. Furthermore, both countries are regional powers and have an active interest in regional security. Indeed, it has been argued by many that Australia has more in common with Japan than many of our geographically closer neighbours. This must never be confused with the notion that we should abandon the interests of our neighbours. To do so would contradict our commitment to globalisation. However, it must be recognised that Australia has an opportunity to cement strong and productive relationships with world powers such as Japan and the United States. These are not relationships of prestige; they are relationships which would give Australia an opportunity to be a real leader in our international region.

The controversial but often misunderstood currency swap of $1.35 billion to assist Thailand's troubled dormant economy is evidence of our growing leadership role in the immediate region. It demonstrates to our regional neighbours that Australia's commitment to Asia is much more than rhetoric. It may, for instance, convince Malaysia that Australia should have a place at the annual meetings of the Asia-Europe meeting, ASEM. It is also worth considering what the response would have been had Australia declined the request for support organised for the IMF. What message would this have sent to our Asian neighbours?

Likewise, the United States have also adopted a responsible proactive approach to Cambodia's democratic and consequent social problems. It is not just evidence of the compatibility in foreign policies between our countries, nor is it merely evidence of the emphases that both countries place on globalisation and bilateral relations. The involvement of the United States demonstrates that the rule of law, an independent judiciary and a government accountable through elections are essential in maintaining peace and facilitating social and economic development in Cambodia. This economic development will, in turn, benefit Australia.

The struggle to establish a legitimate workable democracy in Cambodia has been a matter of great international concern. The principal motivation has been a humanitarian concern. However, there also exists the understanding that several countries can indirectly gain from Cambodia's political and, thus, fiscal stability. Australia and the world have invested billions of dollars in Cambodian industry, commerce and infrastructure since the embryonic stages of democracy in that country. Any responsible strategy to protect our investment, while simultaneously fostering political freedom for the people of Cambodia, must incorporate a long‐term strategy involving democracy and political freedom.

Although the recent attempt to establish an administratively workable democracy in Cambodia failed, the international community should not be discouraged. Tangible gains toward the democratisation of Cambodia have been achieved. The democratisation of Cambodia has been added to by the efforts of a number of nations and agencies. The National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, NDI, is one such agency. The NDI are assisting two coalitions of non‐government organisations, the Committee for Free and Fair Elections and the Coalition for Free and Fair elections. These organisations have been structured to orchestrate a national civic education program, in addition to monitoring the coordination and implementation of the proposed elections.

However, it cannot be denied that there still exist several barriers and obstacles to securing an environment that is conducive to a fair election. This is largely due to escalating tensions between the ruling coalition partners, the CPP and Funcipec. Joint initiatives to establish a framework for the conduct of a national election to date have failed, leaving the process stalled. The national assembly vote on 6 August to replace the duly elected First Prime Minister, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, cannot be objectively regarded as authentic and legitimate. It was rather the product of coercion and sinister motives. Reports of intimidation and voting under fear of threats of violence are numerous.

Since the bloody coup of earlier this year, all indications are that Second Prime Minister Hun Sen and the CPP have consolidated their control and dominance over the Cambodian government, police, judiciary and military. A systematic campaign of identification, isolation and duress has resulted in the detention of an unknown number of political activists. There are proportionately substantiated claims that up to 40 to 60 royalist supporters were executed in the aftermath of the coup.

There is little likelihood that free and fair elections will ever be conducted in the existing political climate. Accordingly, it is not conceivable that genuine democratic elections can be achieved by May 1998. There is no evidence to suggest the present government has a sincere commitment to the democratic process. The 20 parliamentarians or counterparts who fled Cambodia in fear of their lives continue to live in exile, mostly in Bangkok. A sincere attempt to conduct an election must allow these elected representatives to return to contest the next election should they wish to do so. Assurances from the present Cambodian government are clearly insufficient. The international community needs evidence. The international community cannot afford to abdicate its responsibility to protect Cambodia's delicate and fragile democratic gains. We must be committed to a democratic vision for Cambodia; we must be faithful to that vision.

The white paper highlights the fact that, despite the world's enduring tension and its emerging threats, we cannot and must not choose escapism over engagement. There are a number of issues that I would like to have touched on in the white paper that I did not have time for this morning. They cover things like the Cambodian seat at the United Nations and who should fill it; our response and government attitude to the ending of IMF and World Bank aid to Cambodia that occurred out of the United States; the aid the Australian government could give to the Union for Democratic Cambodia that operates in Bangkok, which consists of an alliance between Khmer Nation, Khmer Neutral, Funcipec and the Buddhist Liberal Democratic Party. I might leave that for another day.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Plane Safe Inquiry Report: Government Response

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 26 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the statement to the House (Hansard , 5 December 1996, page 7869) concerning the recommendations of the Planesafe report,(a) will he provide the specific results of each random audit conducted of maintenance organisations,(b) what specific information is he able to provide of the results of actions taken to address the problem of unauthorised spare parts and (c) what assurance can he give that bogus spare parts (i) are not in place on operating regular public transport aircraft or charter aircraft and (ii) will not be used or fitted to regular public transport aircraft or charter aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) 12 special integrated audits of small passenger carrying operators and their maintenance organisations were conducted in 1996. Four such audits have been carried out so far this year. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has advised that a summary of the overall results of the 12 special integrated audits conducted in 1996 was published in the Safety Systems Assessment of Passenger‐Carrying Operators Report. A copy of the report has been forwarded to the honourable member.

(b) and (c) The Australian Civil Aviation Regulations (CARs) identify the required documentation that must accompany aircraft parts or materials prior to installation or use on Australian registered aircraft.

CASA's Regulatory Review Program is currently reviewing Australian requirements relating to aircraft parts and materials used in maintenance, in order to clarify the current regulations and to harmonise with international standards.

To ensure compliance with CARs, holders of Air Operator Certificates (AOC) and maintenance organisations that hold CAR 30 Certificate of Approval (CofA) are audited, on a regular basis, under the CASA Aviation Safety Surveillance Program. Part of the audit is to assess documentation used to identify suitability, serviceability and authenticity of components supplied to an AOC holder or maintenance organisation, either held in store or fitted to aircraft.
Should the audit identify a non‐compliance against the CARs, CASA will take appropriate enforcement action in accordance with its Compliance and Enforcement Manual.

CASA's role is also to educate and foster awareness within the Australian aviation industry. Advisory material such as the Flight Safety Magazine, Civil Aviation Advisory Publications and Airworthiness Advisory Circulars are produced by CASA to alert industry to problems relating to unapproved parts and to inform industry of acceptable methods to ensure compliance with regulatory requirements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 1 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Mr P Harris, the First Assistant Secretary of his Department, state in a Senate Estimates Committee on Wednesday, 20 August 1997, in response to a question concerning aircraft movements at Essendon Airport that there were three sources of data; it so, what steps will he take to ensure that bidders for Essendon Airport are provided with reliable information on aircraft movements.
(2) Has he or his Department advised the Office of Asset Sales of the discrepancy in Essendon Airport aircraft movement statistics.
(3) What is the Federal Airports Corporation's definition of an aircraft movement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department has advised that the three sources of data for aircraft movements at Essendon referred to by Mr P Harris are the Federal Airports Corporation's (FAC) annual report, AirServices Australia official movement figures and the Victorian Municipal Aerodrome Owners Association. AirServices Australia publish their movement data in the bimonthly AirServices Aviation Bulletin and this is the information that the Department considers is the most reliable. The Department's Avstats unit is providing movement data for the sales process. This information will be based on the statistics published by AirServices Australia. Bidders will receive this data as part of the Information Memorandum on Essendon Airport.
(2) The Department has advised that they have informed the Office of Asset Sales of discrepancies found between the FAC annual report and AirServices Australia figures in previous years.
(3) The FAC have advised that an aircraft movement is defined as any take‐off or landing at an airport.
